triplets: Edible fruit produced by herbaceous plants of the genus Musa, cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions
Eating raw, making smoothies, desserts, baked goods, cooking, and baby food
Fleshy fruit pulp, peel, and seeds (tiny, undeveloped in cultivated varieties)
Peel that protects the fruit and can be removed before consumption
Pulp, the soft and edible portion rich in carbohydrates, fiber, vitamins, and minerals
Typically yellow when ripe; green when unripe, and brown spots may develop as the fruit ripens further
Banana plant, tropical/subtropical agricultural ecosystems, and fruit supply chains
Various farmers and commercial growers who cultivate banana plants for local and export markets
Approximately 120–150 grams per fruit depending on variety and size
Approximately 20 cm per fruit, varying slightly with cultivar
Typically 1–2 weeks after harvest under proper storage; the banana plant itself produces fruit for several years before replacement
